node.title: A Cruet for Dressing or Syrup
node.description: These borosilicate glass vessels from Hungary are an attractive accompaniment to the dinner table.
node.content: ["These well-designed cruets from Civilian Objects, a company created by Nicko Elliott and Ksenia Kagner of the New York design studio Civilian, make a fine house gift or handy accessory. While they are intended for oil or vinegar, or a combination, they also beg to be filled with maple syrup for a holiday breakfast because the design that makes them so suitable for oil applies to syrup as well. They have an elegant spout, a collar to catch any drips and a textured etched finish for the stopper to prevent leaking. Made of borosilicate glass, a material that was created for laboratory equipment, they\u2019re produced in Hungary by Trendglas Jena.", "Follow NYT Food on Twitter and NYT Cooking on Instagram, Facebook and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice."]
